choices.text: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist
It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel
Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about prasugrel? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a pro-drug

 

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is metabolized by the liver to its active metabolite, which is an inhibitor of P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors. This active metabolite irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation, making prasugrel a potent antiplatelet agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist is incorrect because prasugrel is not a P2Y12 agonist but rather an inhibitor.

 

Option B It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel: It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel is incorrect because prasugrel is actually more potent than clopidogrel.

 

Option D. Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding: Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding is incorrect because omeprazole can interfere with the activation of prasugrel to its active metabolite, reducing its antiplatelet effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prasugrel is a pro-drug that, upon hepatic metabolism, becomes an active metabolite that irreversibly inhibits the P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors, thus preventing platelet aggregation and making it a potent antiplatelet agent.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drugs act at the site marked by the arrow? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tiagabine

 

Explanation: 


Tiagabine acts by inhibiting GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1), which is responsible for the reuptake of GABA from the synapse. By blocking this transporter, Tiagabine increases the synaptic concentration of GABA, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and providing antiepileptic effects. The name "Tiagabine" itself suggests its mechanism - Transport Inhibitor of GABA or GAT-1 inhibitor.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Vigabatrin: Incorrect. It inhibits GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA breakdown, not the GABA transporter. This increases GABA levels through a different mechanism.

 

 

Option B. Valproate: Incorrect. It has multiple mechanisms of action, primarily involving sodium channel blockade and enhancement of GABA-mediated inhibition, but does not specifically target GAT-1.

 

Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist and enhances GABA-mediated inhibition through different mechanisms, not through GAT-1 inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:


Tiagabine inhibits GABA reuptake by blocking the GABA transporter (GAT-1), leading to increased extracellular GABA and enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission, making it an effective treatment for epilepsy.

questions.text: A patient presents with the skin lesion shown below. What can be used for treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

 

The image depicts a patient with a "Casal's necklace" rash, a characteristic sign of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency.

 

Pellagra is referred to as the "4D disease": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia, and Death. The treatment of choice for pellagra is nicotinamide, also known as vitamin B3 or niacin, which addresses the niacin deficiency underlying the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): While important for various bodily functions, it's not the specific treatment for pellagra.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Primarily involved in vision and immune function, not relevant to pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Crucial for wound healing and immune response, but doesn't address niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal's necklace, a dermatological manifestation with a symmetrical rash resembling a necklace around the neck, is a hallmark sign of pellagra, a condition resulting from niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. The primary treatment for pellagra involves niacin supplementation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male arrives at the emergency department with symptoms indicative of an acute ischemic stroke. It is decided to administer recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA), with a total dose of 80 mg. How much should be given as the initial bolus dose? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8 mg

 

For the administration of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) in acute ischemic stroke, the initial bolus dose should be 10% of the total dose. Therefore, for a total dose of 80 mg, the initial bolus dose should be 8 mg (which is 10% of 80 mg).

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering rtPA for acute ischemic stroke, the initial bolus dose should be 10% of the total dose. For an 80 mg total dose, the initial bolus is 8 mg, followed by an infusion of the remaining dose over 60 minutes.

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

Explanation

 

Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.

 

Reason for decerebrate rigidity:

 

  • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by

 

  1. γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  2. Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  3. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  4. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: Correct as part of the characterization of decerebrate rigidity. The increased discharge rate of the γ efferent neurons enhances the muscle spindle responses, contributing to increased muscle tone.

 

Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: Correct, this increased excitability leads to the hyperactivity of motor neurons, particularly those controlling the extensor muscles.

 

Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: Correct, unlike spinal shock, which involves a temporary reduction or loss of reflex activity below the level of a spinal cord injury, decerebration does not produce a similar transient reduction in reflexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by an increase in extensor muscle tone due to enhanced activity of the γ motor neurons and increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, without inducing effects similar to spinal shock. Rigidity does not occur in all muscles of the body but is more pronounced in antigravity extensor muscles.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in the TNM stage T4b of breast cancer? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Skin erythema involving > 1/3rd surface

 

T4b stage of breast cancer involves skin invasion with specific manifestations. According to TNM staging, T4b includes direct skin invasion presenting as ulceration of the skin, satellite skin nodules, or peau d'orange (orange peel appearance due to lymphatic obstruction). These changes must involve less than one-third of the breast skin surface. When skin erythema involves more than one-third of the breast surface (>1/3rd surface), it is classified as T4d (inflammatory breast cancer), not T4b. Therefore, skin erythema involving more than one-third of the surface is not included in T4b staging but rather defines T4d disease. The distinction is important because inflammatory breast cancer (T4d) has a different prognosis and treatment approach compared to T4b disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulceration: This is incorrect as an answer because ulceration is indeed included in T4b staging. Skin ulceration represents direct tumor invasion through the dermis and epidermis, which is a defining feature of T4b breast cancer.

 

Option B. Satellite nodules: This is incorrect as an answer because satellite nodules are included in T4b staging. These are small tumor deposits in the skin separate from the main tumor mass, indicating advanced local disease with skin involvement.

 

Option D. Peau d'orange: This is incorrect as an answer because peau d'orange is a classic sign included in T4b staging. It results from dermal lymphatic invasion causing skin edema and dimpling that resembles orange peel, representing skin involvement without necessarily being inflammatory breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T4b breast cancer includes skin ulceration, satellite nodules, and peau d'orange affecting less than one-third of breast skin surface, while skin erythema involving more than one-third of the surface is classified as T4d (inflammatory breast cancer).

 

TNM Staging for Breast Cancer:

 

T - Tumor Size (maximum)

questions.text: Which of the options is considered the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Designated Microscopy Centre 

 

  • Among the given options, the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure is the Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC). This remains same for the new National TB Elimination Program 2020 too.
  • The DMC is the first point of contact for patients seeking diagnosis and treatment for tuberculosis (TB) and is responsible for collecting sputum samples and conducting smear microscopy to detect the presence of TB bacteria. The DMCs are established at the periphery level of the healthcare system, such as at the level of Primary Health Centers or Community Health Centers, to ensure that TB diagnosis and treatment services are accessible to people in their own communities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. District TB Centre: This option is higher up in the hierarchy than the DMC. It is responsible for the supervision and monitoring of TB control activities within the district, making it central but not the most peripheral.
 

Option B. Intermediate Reference Laboratory:  The IRL provides quality assurance for TB diagnosis and conducts drug susceptibility testing. It is a specialized facility that supports the network by confirming diagnoses and resistance patterns, placed higher in the organizational hierarchy than DMCs.
 

Option C. Tuberculosis Unit:  While the Tuberculosis Unit is responsible for providing treatment and care to TB patients, it is not as peripheral as the DMC. The TU operates within a more integrated role in patient management and care continuum than the DMC, which is strictly focused on initial diagnostics.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

The Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) remains a foundational component in the RNTCP for its role in accessible, community-level TB diagnosis and initial management. Its position as the most peripheral center in the hierarchy underscores its critical function in early TB detection and intervention.

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague. This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.


 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:

 

 

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.

 

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.

 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Species Phlebotomus argentipes: belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C. Ixodes Tick: transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer was brought to the emergency after he suddenly became unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees Fahrenheit and his skin turgor was decreased. Which of the following would not be seen in the patient?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

Explanation

 

In the scenario described, the patient likely suffers from heatstroke, characterized by a high body temperature (105°F), altered consciousness, and dehydration (indicated by decreased skin turgor).

 

Heatstroke is a severe form of heat illness that occurs when the body's heat-dissipating mechanisms fail. One of the classic signs, especially in exertional heatstroke, is the cessation of sweating, despite the elevated body temperature. This lack of sweating is due to dehydration and the body's inability to maintain adequate heat loss through evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Tachypnea - Rapid, deep breathing (Kussmaul breathing) can be seen in heatstroke

 

Option B: Hypotension - Dehydration and vasodilation in an attempt to dissipate heat can result in hypotension in heatstroke.

 

Option D: Red hot skin - Heatstroke patients can present with hot, flushed skin due to increased blood flow to the skin surface and the body's inability to dissipate heat effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Difference between Fever and Heatstroke is as follows:

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: Diphtheria toxin MOA is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

 

Diphtheria toxin exerts its toxic effects by inhibiting protein synthesis in the host cell. The mechanism involves the ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which is a critical component in the protein synthesis machinery of the cell. By modifying EF-2, diphtheria toxin prevents the translocation step in protein elongation, effectively halting protein production. This leads to cell death and contributes to the pathogenic effects of the infection.

 

Mnemonic "Delhi Public Secondary School" (DPSS): The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acting on 60s Ribosome: This is incorrect because diphtheria toxin specifically targets elongation factor 2 (EF-2) rather than the ribosome directly. It interferes with protein synthesis by modifying EF-2, not by acting on the ribosome.

 

Option B. Increasing cAMP: This option is incorrect as it describes the mechanism of action of other bacterial toxins like those produced by Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). These toxins increase the intracellular levels of cAMP by activating adenyl cyclase, which is not the mechanism for diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C. Decreasing cGMP: This is incorrect. The mechanism involving the decrease of cGMP is not relevant to diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin's action is specific to inhibiting protein synthesis through the ADP ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MOA

 

The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis by modifying EF-2: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin. (Mnemonic: Delhi Public Secondary School /DPSS)

 

The four toxin act by increasing cAMP: Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). (Mnemonic: Be Very Efficient Boy/BVEB)

questions.text: A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads: superior (or upper) and inferior (or lower). The superior head attaches to the articular disc and the capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This muscle plays a crucial role in the opening of the mouth, protrusion of the mandible, and moving the jaw from side to side. Dysfunction or spasms of this muscle could contribute to jaw locking during yawning. The lateral pterygoid is, therefore, closely associated with the movements and function of the TMJ.

 

All Innervated by CN V3

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle originates from the temporal fossa and inserts onto the coronoid process of the mandible. It's primarily responsible for closing the mouth and is involved in elevating and retracting the mandible. It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ, but it plays a role in jaw movement.

 

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is similar in function to the masseter muscle and helps in elevating the mandible, thus assisting in closing the mouth. It also plays a role in moving the jaw from side to side. However, like the temporalis, it doesn't directly attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option D. Masseter: The masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing). It originates from the zygomatic arch and inserts onto the lateral aspect of the mandibular angle and ramus. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible, assisting in closing the mouth. It does not have an attachment to the articular disc of the TMJ but is important for jaw function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle, particularly its superior head, is uniquely attached to the TMJ's articular disc and plays a pivotal role in jaw movements including mouth opening and lateral movements, making it relevant in cases of jaw locking.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Support and education

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks.

 

The primary management for postpartum blues is support and education about the condition, emphasizing its transient nature and differentiating it from the more severe postpartum depression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Useful in postpartum depression but not needed for the milder blues.

 

Option B. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for postpartum depression but is not the primary treatment for transient postpartum blues.

 

Option C. Lithium carbonate: Not indicated for postpartum blues or depression; used mainly for bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with the following x-ray of knee. It is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

  • The given image shows the Codman’s triangle which is a characteristic radiological finding in osteosarcoma. 
  • Codman's triangle is a periosteal reaction, seen on X-ray, characterized by the lifting of the periosteum with a triangular piece of dense calcification underneath. 
  • This appearance is indicative of an aggressive periosteal reaction. 
  • It is commonly associated with malignant lesions or chronic processes, with osteosarcoma being a typical example.
  • Sun Ray Appearance is another X-ray finding where there are multiple radiating spicules extending from a bone, resembling rays of the sun. 

 

Note - While these periosteal reactions are highly suggestive of certain bone conditions, they are not diagnostic on their own. The definitive diagnosis of bone lesions, whether benign or malignant, is confirmed through a tissue biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma can show aggressive periosteal reactions such as an onion peel appearance.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: This is a benign bone growth that typically have a distinct appearance with an exostosis pointing away from the joint.

 

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: This condition can show a periosteal reaction, but it is usually a solid, narrow zone reaction and not the wide zone reaction like Codman's triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text:
A persistent alcoholic patient presents with convulsions and impaired sensorium. He has been drinking for ten years and consumes 24 units every day. His most recent drink was two days ago. He is discovered to have auditory hallucinations as well as secondary delusions. What method will you employ to manage this patient?

 

  1. Diazepam
  2. Thiamine
  3. Naltrexone
  4. Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, specifically delirium tremens, characterized by tremors, altered sensorium, hallucinations, seizures, and agitation.

 

1. Diazepam: Benzodiazepines, like diazepam, are the first line of treatment for alcohol withdrawal symptoms and can help reduce the severity of symptoms, prevent seizures, and can be titrated based on the severity of withdrawal.

 

2. Thiamine: Chronic alcoholics are at risk for thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is important to administer thiamine before or with the first dose of glucose-containing fluids or foods to prevent precipitating or exacerbating Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Naltrexone: This is an opioid antagonist that is used to decrease alcohol cravings. It is not directly useful in treating acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

4. Flupenthixol depot injection: This is an antipsychotic medication. It is not the primary treatment for alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 472-473.

questions.text: The marked landmark corresponds to which structure?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Marked landmark corresponds to ulnar nerve

 

Arrow points toward the medial epicondyle and Ulnar nerve passes below it.

 

The ulnar nerve gives no branches in the arm. It runs distally through the axilla medial to the axillary artery and between it and the vein, continuing distally medial to the brachial artery as far as the midarm. Here it pierces the medial intermuscular septum, inclining medially as it descends anterior to the medial head of triceps to the interval between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon, with the superior ulnar collateral artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve enters the arm lateral to the brachial artery. Near the insertion of coracobrachialis it crosses in front of the artery, descending medial to it to the cubital fossa where it is posterior to the bicipital aponeurosis and anterior to brachialis, separated by the latter from the elbow joint.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: supplies the long head of triceps, and gives rise to the posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm which supplies the skin along the posterior surface of the upper arm. It then spirals obliquely across the back of the humerus, lying posterior to the uppermost fibres of the medial head of triceps which separate the nerve from the bone in the first part of the spiral groove. On reaching the lateral side of the humerus it pierces the lateral intermuscular septum to enter the anterior compartment; it then descends deep in a furrow between brachialis and proximally brachioradialis, then more distally extensor carpi radialis longus

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the anterior rami (branches) of the spinal nerves C5, C6, and C7. After its origin, the musculocutaneous nerve courses downward through the axilla (armpit) alongside the axillary artery. It then enters the anterior compartment of the arm by piercing through the coracobrachialis muscle. It provide motor innervation to the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. These muscles include coracobrachialis and biceps brachii.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nerves related to the humerus are:

 

  • Axillary nerve is at the surgical neck
  • Ulnar nerve is at the medial epicondyle
  • Radial nerve is at the spiral groove of the shaft of the humerus.

choices.text: Pituitary gland

questions.text: IGF-I is synthesized by which of the following organ? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liver

 

Explanation

 

The predominant organ producing insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) is the liver. IGF-I is produced in response to stimulation by growth hormone (GH), which is primarily secreted by the pituitary gland. However, while GH stimulates IGF-I production, it is the liver that is responsible for producing the majority of circulating IGF-I in the body.

 

Growth hormone acts on the liver to form small proteins called "somatomedins"

 

  • Somatomedins increases bone growth in all aspect
  • Also called as insulin-like growth factor (IGF) as effects are similar to insulin
  • Four types are present - Most important is somatomedin C, specifically referred to as "insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1)
  • Binds to carrier protein in blood
  • Half-life - about 20 Hrs
  • Blood concentration of IGF-1, follows the levels of growth hormone.
  • Growth effects of GH are mostly attributed to somatomedin (rather than its direct effect on bones & peripheral tissues)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pituitary gland: Incorrect because while the pituitary gland secretes growth hormone that stimulates IGF-I production, it does not synthesize IGF-I itself.

 

Option C. Pancreas: Incorrect because the pancreas is involved in the production of insulin and other digestive enzymes, not IGF-I.

 

Option D. Adrenal glands: Incorrect because the adrenal glands produce corticosteroids and catecholamines, not IGF-I.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver is the primary organ responsible for the synthesis of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I), which is stimulated by growth hormone secreted from the pituitary gland.

 

Ref– Textbook of Medical physiology Guyton and Hall, 11th edition, page no. 924

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein’s procedure

 

The following surgical options are used to treat rectal prolapse:

 

This procedure involves the use of a prosthetic mesh that is placed around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory. It is performed using the abdominal approach, which is difficult but has a lower recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delorme's operation: This surgical option involves the circumferential stripping of the rectal mucosa over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, and the excess rectal mucosa is excised. It is performed using the perineal approach and is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate than the abdominal approach.

 

Option C. Thiersch operation: This surgical option involves placing a steel wire or nylon tape around the anal canal to manage partial rectal prolapse. It is largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation, and is rarely used.

 

Option D. Altemeier's procedure: This surgical option involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. It is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein's procedure is done for its management using the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is often preferred in elderly patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy. It involves surgeries such as Delorme's mucosectomy and Thiersch's wiring, which have higher recurrence rates than the abdominal approach.

questions.text: In the cadaveric specimen shown, which nerve is marked by the black arrow? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial pectoral nerve

 

The nerve marked in the image is the medial pectoral nerve. This nerve specifically pierces the pectoralis minor muscle. In the pectoral region, the large muscle visible is the pectoralis major, and when this muscle is cut, the pectoralis minor is seen underneath. The medial pectoral nerve is responsible for innervating both the pectoralis minor and major muscles. The distinguishing feature of this nerve is its penetration through the pectoralis minor muscle, making it identifiable in anatomical images.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle and does not have any direct association with the pectoralis muscles or the clavipectoral fascia, making it an incorrect choice in this context.

 

Option B. Lateral pectoral nerve: The lateral pectoral nerve primarily supplies the pectoralis major muscle and pierces the clavipectoral fascia between the clavicle and the pectoralis minor, not the muscle itself. Thus, it is not the nerve marked in the image.

 

Option D. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, located along the lateral thoracic wall, and does not pierce the pectoralis minor, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial pectoral nerve is the nerve that pierces the pectoralis minor muscle and also provides innervation to the pectoralis major.

questions.text: Breast cancer of size 6 x 8 cm with dimpling with invasion of Pectoralis Major and ipsilateral matted axillary nodes belongs to what TNM stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3N2M0

 

  • Tumor size > 5 cm = T3
  • Skin dimpling does not affect T stage (common misconception)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major does not affect T stage
  • Only skin ulceration, peau d'orange, or satellite nodules make it T4b
  • Ipsilateral matted axillary nodes = N2
  • No mention of distant metastasis = M0


Other Options: 

 

Option B. T4bN1M0:

 

  • Skin dimpling alone does not make it T4b
  • N1 represents mobile nodes, while the question mentions matted nodes (N2)
     

Option C. T4aN2M0:

 

  • T4a represents chest wall invasion (not including pectoralis major)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major alone does not make it T4a
     

Option D. T2N2M1:

 

  • T2 is for tumors 2-5 cm, this tumor is > 5 cm

  • No evidence of distant metastasis (M1)

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skin dimpling and pectoralis major invasion do not affect T stage in breast cancer TNM staging
  • T3 stage is for tumors > 5 cm
  • Matted axillary nodes represent N2 disease

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and a fluctuating course, often varying in severity throughout the day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: This is more suggestive of dementia rather than delirium.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: The characteristic feature of delirium is a disturbance in consciousness and attention. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: While hallucinations can be present in delirium, they aren't specific to it. Schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders might also present with auditory hallucinations.

 

Therefore, a fluctuating course is the most suggestive of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is the most common organic mental disorder. It has an acute onset with a fluctuating course. It is most commonly seen in elderly population. It is characterized by disturbed consciousness, and altered attention. Disturbances of sleep-wake cycle, evening worsening of symptoms (sundowning), and floccillations can be seen.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook osf Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

choices.text: Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance
Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance
Creatinine is equal to inulin clearance

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Creatinine clearance? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance

 

  • Creatinine clearance is often used as a measure of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) but it is important to note that it slightly overestimates GFR. This overestimation is because creatinine is not only filtered by the glomerulus but also secreted in small amounts by the renal tubules. Therefore, creatinine clearance is typically greater than inulin clearance.
  • Inulin clearance, on the other hand, is considered the gold standard for measuring GFR. Inulin is a polysaccharide that is freely filtered by the kidneys but neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules. Thus, it provides an accurate measure of the filtration capacity of the kidneys.

 

Clinical Relevance

 

  • Inulin clearance is an accurate measure but is seldom used in clinical practice due to the complexity and cost of the procedure.
  • Creatinine clearance, despite its limitations, is commonly used because it is simpler and cheaper to measure. It requires only serum and urine creatinine levels, making it practical for routine medical evaluations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance: Incorrect because creatinine clearance slightly overestimates GFR due to additional renal tubular secretion.

 

Option C. Creatinine clearance is equal to inulin clearance: Incorrect because the secretion of creatinine leads to higher clearance values compared to inulin.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as option B correctly describes the relationship between creatinine and inulin clearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatinine clearance is commonly used to estimate GFR but it is greater than inulin clearance due to slight secretion of creatinine by the renal tubules. In contrast, inulin clearance, being neither secreted nor reabsorbed, provides a more accurate measurement of renal filtration function.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to prevent painful vaso-occlusive crises and decrease long-term complications in sickle cell anemia? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydroxyurea.

 

Hydroxyurea is widely used in the management of sickle cell anemia. It helps to increase the concentration of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in the bloodstream, which is less likely to participate in the sickling process that characterizes sickle cell disease. By reducing the sickling of red blood cells, hydroxyurea lowers the incidence of vaso-occlusive crises that cause pain and can lead to organ damage. Additionally, the drug has been shown to have a positive impact on the long-term complications associated with sickle cell anemia, including reducing the risk of stroke and other serious events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate plus leucovorin: This combination is not used for sickle cell anemia. Methotrexate is primarily used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases, and leucovorin is given to mitigate the side effects of methotrexate.

 

Option C. Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid that is not used to treat sickle cell anemia or its complications. It has no role in preventing vaso-occlusive crises. Rather L-glutamine is the amino acid that is used in sickle cell disease.

 

Option D. Eltrombopag: Eltrombopag is a medication that stimulates platelet production and is used in conditions like chronic immune thrombocytopenia. It is not indicated for the treatment or prevention of complications in sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydroxyurea is the primary medication used to prevent painful vaso-occlusive crises and decrease long-term complications in sickle cell anemia by increasing the concentration of fetal hemoglobin (HbF).

questions.text: What treatment should be avoided for a male patient in his mid-40s who was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident, and presents with a heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, and an X-ray image of his chest? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest tube insertion

 

Given Scenario with x ray shows left sided traumatic diaphragmatic rupture with herniation of stomach. Nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia can be done. However, intercostal drain should not be put as it would traumatic the herniated content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The provided image displays an elevated left hemidiaphragm with stomach herniated into thorax, likely due to a diaphragmatic hernia resulting from blunt trauma in a road traffic accident.

 

  • Chest tube insertion or thoracostomy is not recommended in cases of diaphragmatic hernia and is contraindicated
  • Chest tube insertion is generally indicated for pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, among others, but is contraindicated in the presence of pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.
  • To insert a chest tube, the 5th intercostal space should be accessed anterior to the midaxillary line, within the triangle of safety, which is located above the level of the nipple and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • Acquired diaphragmatic hernia does not contraindicate nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not carry parasympathetic fibers? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trochlear

 

Explanation:

 

Among the cranial nerves, only the oculomotor (CN III), facial (CN VII), glossopharyngeal (CN IX), and vagus (CN X) nerves carry parasympathetic fibers. These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity in the head, neck, and face area. The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is not involved in parasympathetic innervation.

 

The parasympathetic ganglia associated with these cranial nerves are:

 

  • Oculomotor (CN III): Ciliary ganglion, related to the eye
  • Facial (CN VII): Pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia, causing secretion from nasal, palatine, and submandibular glands
  • Glossopharyngeal (CN IX): Otic ganglion
  • Vagus (CN X): Responsible for secretion from the gastrointestinal tract (GIT)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial: The facial nerve (CN VII) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia.

 

Option C. Oculomotor: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the ciliary ganglion.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the otic ganglion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cranial nerves that carry parasympathetic fibers are CN III, CN VII, CN IX, and CN X (3, 7, 9, 10). These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity and secretion in the head, neck, and face area, as well as the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text:
You are employed at a primary health center (PHC) located in an area with a high risk of earthquakes. What actions would you take to ensure readiness for potential emergencies? [NEET PG 2022]

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1,2,3

 

To ensure readiness for potential emergencies in a high-risk earthquake area, the following actions are crucial:

 

  1. Disaster Preparedness: Ensuring all financial and other resources are available. This involves mobilizing funds and resources for quick evacuation and emergency response.
  2. Increase Public Awareness: Conducting campaigns and using loudspeakers to inform the public about earthquake preparedness measures and safety protocols.
  3. Conduct a Simulation: Performing disaster simulations and assessing the response to identify areas for improvement and ensure the effectiveness of the emergency plan.

 

These steps are essential components of a comprehensive disaster preparedness strategy and done by someone working in a PHC situated in a high seismic zone. A medical officer is supposed to provide instructions by any communication method possible to manage through the calamity.

 

Roles and responsibilities of medical officer of PHC when posted in Seismic areas

 

  • Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized at the time of disaster for quick evacuation
  • Preparedness to handle emergency
  • Disaster simulation practices and then check the response

 

Other Options:

 

While following instructions from higher officials is important during an actual disaster, it is not a proactive preparedness measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency preparedness is a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It involves the following steps:

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Evaluate the risk of disaster
  5. Information sessions coordination with news media
  6. Adopt standards and regulations

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). An abdominal CT scan reveals a lesion in the right liver lobe characterized by irregular borders, several partitions, and varied densities. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoebic liver abscess

 

The most probable diagnosis in this case is C) Amoebic liver abscess.

 

1. Clinical Presentation:

 

  • The patient presents with weight loss and fever, which are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.
  • A history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago may suggest an underlying gastrointestinal infection, likely to be amebic colitis.

 

2. Physical Examination Findings:

 

  • Tenderness in the right hypochondrium (upper right abdomen) suggests liver involvement.
  • Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is a common finding in liver abscesses.

 

3. Imaging Findings:

 

  • The description of the lesion on the abdominal CT scan is characteristic of an amoebic liver abscess. These abscesses typically have irregular borders, several partitions (internal septations), and varied densities due to necrotic tissue and pus formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic liver abscess: Can also cause similar symptoms and imaging findings but will often present with high grade fever and chills, and is usually multiple.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging and is caused by the Echinococcus parasite. It will not be preceded by a colitis type of event. It's less likely given the description of irregular borders and partitions in the lesion.

 

Option D. Hemangiomas: Hemangiomas are usually benign vascular tumors and are unlikely to cause the presented symptoms or imaging findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination findings, and the characteristic imaging features of an irregular, partitioned lesion in the liver makes amoebic liver abscess the most probable diagnosis in this case

 

 

ANCHOVY SAUCE – STERILE PUS SEEN IN AMEBIC LIVER ABSCESS

questions.text: Which of the following cancers is not protective by use of combined oral contraceptives? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breast cancer

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) provide protection against several types of cancers through their hormonal effects. This protective effect can be remembered using the mnemonic "CEO" - Colorectal, Endometrial, and Ovarian cancers. However, OCPs are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and possibly cervical cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometrial cancer: Incorrect. OCPs are protective against endometrial cancer due to the progesterone component which counteracts unopposed estrogen effects on the endometrium.

 

Option C. Colorectal cancer: Incorrect. OCPs provide protection against colorectal cancer through their hormonal mechanisms.

 

Option D. Ovarian cancer: Incorrect. OCPs significantly reduce the risk of ovarian cancer by suppressing ovulation and reducing the repetitive damage to ovarian epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCPs provide protection against three types of cancers (CEO - Colorectal, Endometrial, and Ovarian) but increase the risk of breast cancer and potentially cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

 

Insidious onset of symptoms, where the symptoms develop slowly and subtly over time, tends to indicate a poorer prognosis when compared to an abrupt or sudden onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Schizophrenia's prognosis varies based on several factors:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions are usually more responsive to antipsychotic medications, marking them as a better prognostic factor.

 

Option B. Late age of onset: Late age of onset indeed is a better prognostic factor. Early-onset schizophrenia tends to be more severe and has a poorer prognosis than schizophrenia that begins in adulthood.

 

Option D. Associated with depression: If a patient with schizophrenia also has depressive symptoms, the prognosis might be somewhat better since affective symptoms might respond to treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: Which of the options was initiated to ensure complete immunization of children? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mission Indradhanush

 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MISSION INDRADHANUSH INCLUDES

 

  1. Polio
  2. Diphtheria
  3. Pertussis
  4. Tetanus
  5. TB
  6. Measles
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Rota Virus
  9. MR
  10. IPV
  11. JE
  12. HiB
  13. PCV

questions.text: In the given image, the tendon marked by the arrow is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the anterior compartment of the forearm, focusing on the tendons near the wrist. The arrow is pointing to a tendon that runs from the forearm to the wrist and to the palm. This tendon belongs to the flexor carpi radialis muscle. The flexor carpi radialis is one of the superficial flexor muscles of the forearm. It plays a crucial role in flexion and abduction of the wrist.

 

Flexor Carpi Radialis: The flexor carpi radialis tendon is located just lateral to the palmaris longus tendon. It is prominent and easily palpable in many individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexor carpi ulnaris: This is incorrect. The flexor carpi ulnaris tendon is located medial to the palmaris longus tendon and runs towards the pisiform bone.

 

Option C. Flexor digitorum superficialis: This is incorrect. The flexor digitorum superficialis tendons are deeper and run to the fingers, responsible for flexion of the middle phalanges.

 

Option D. Palmaris longus: This is incorrect. The palmaris longus tendon runs from the forearm to the palm and is more centrally located in the wrist. It is a thin tendon that is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor carpi radialis is a superficial flexor muscle of the forearm with a prominent tendon that runs from the forearm to the base of the second and third metacarpals, playing a key role in wrist flexion and abduction.

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common type of hernia in females? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal

 

While it is commonly believed that femoral hernias are the most frequent type of hernia in females, this is not the case. The most common type of hernia in both males and females is the inguinal hernia, specifically the indirect inguinal hernia.

 

Inguinal hernias occur due to a weakness in the abdominal wall and the presence of a natural opening, the deep inguinal ring. Indirect inguinal hernias, which pass through this deep ring, are particularly common. Although femoral hernias are more commonly seen in women than in men, their overall incidence is much lower compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal: This type of hernia is less common than indirect inguinal hernias and occurs due to weakness in the floor of the inguinal canal. It is not the most common type in females.

 

Option C. Femoral: Although more common in women than in men, femoral hernias have a much lower overall incidence compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Obturator: This is a rare type of hernia and is not commonly seen in the general population, including females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of hernia in females, as in males, is the indirect inguinal hernia. Despite the misconception, femoral hernias, though more common in women than men, are less frequent overall.

questions.text: In a patient who has undergone gastrectomy, vitamin supplementation required is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vit B12

 

After a gastrectomy, the patient's stomach no longer has parietal cells, which are responsible for secreting intrinsic factor. The intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of Vitamin B12 in the small intestine. Without intrinsic factor, Vitamin B12 cannot be effectively absorbed, leading to a deficiency. This is why patients who have undergone a gastrectomy require supplemental Vitamin B12 to prevent deficiency, which can lead to conditions such as pernicious anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vit C: Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, wound healing, and as an antioxidant. However, its absorption is not dependent on the stomach or intrinsic factor, so a gastrectomy patient does not necessarily need supplemental Vitamin C.

 

Option B. Vit D: Vitamin D is important for calcium absorption and bone health, but its absorption is primarily related to the function of the liver and kidneys, not the stomach. Thus, a gastrectomy patient does not require supplemental Vitamin D specifically due to the surgery.

 

Option D. Vit A: Vitamin A is crucial for vision, immune function, and skin health. Its absorption is fat-dependent and occurs in the small intestine. A gastrectomy does not directly impact Vitamin A absorption, so supplementation is not typically necessary unless there is another underlying deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients who have undergone a gastrectomy require supplemental Vitamin B12 due to the loss of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for the absorption of this vitamin

questions.text: Thyroid hormones play a crucial role in metabolism, growth, and development. They exert their effects through specific receptor types in target cells. Through which type of receptor does thyroid hormone primarily act?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nuclear receptors

 

Thyroid hormones act via nuclear receptors. These receptors, when bound by thyroid hormones, regulate the transcription of specific genes, influencing various physiological processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic receptors: Incorrect. While some steroid hormones act via cytoplasmic receptors, thyroid hormones primarily function through receptors located in the nucleus.

 

Option B. Tyrosine kinase receptors: Incorrect. Tyrosine kinase receptors are typically associated with growth factors and cytokines, not thyroid hormones. Thyroid hormones do not activate tyrosine kinase pathways directly.

 

Option D. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR): Incorrect. GPCRs are a large family of cell surface receptors that respond to a variety of external signals, but thyroid hormones do not act through these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid hormones primarily exert their effects through nuclear receptors, influencing gene transcription and various physiological processes.

questions.text: A patient with mild to moderate renal failure requires reversal of muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this purpose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

 

Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant used during surgeries to facilitate intubation and muscle relaxation. After the procedure, it is often necessary to reverse the effects of vecuronium to allow the patient to regain muscle function.

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent (SRBA) specifically designed to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, including vecuronium and rocuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecules, effectively reducing their availability to bind to nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, thereby reversing muscle paralysis.

 

Sugammadex is preferred in patients with mild to moderate renal failure because it is highly effective and works faster than traditional agents like neostigmine. While Sugammadex is contraindicated in severe or end-stage renal disease due to reduced clearance, it can be safely used in mild to moderate renal impairment.

 

Note –

 

Reversal agents for muscle relaxants used in anesthesia include neostigmine and Sugammadex.

 

Neostigmine:

 

  • A cholinergic drug that inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to increased acetylcholine.
  • Causes cholinergic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine.
  • Can be used for all muscle relaxants.
  • Can be given in renal disease patients
  • If neostigmine is not an option and the patient has mild to moderate renal failure, Sugammadex is the preferred choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is primarily used to reverse the effects of central nervous system depressants and is not typically used for reversing non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium.

 

Option B. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is used in the management of Alzheimer's disease and other types of dementia, not for reversing muscle relaxants.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used for short-term muscle relaxation, such as during intubation. It is not used for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium and, in fact, would induce more muscle relaxation rather than reverse it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the appropriate agent for reversing the effects of vecuronium in patients with mild to moderate renal failure due to its specific action on non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and its faster onset of action.

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

The described clinical picture is consistent with Delirium tremens (DT). DT is a severe and potentially life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal. It typically appears 48 to 72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by agitation, disorientation, paranoid delusions, tremors, autonomic hyperactivity (such as tachycardia and hypertension), and visual or tactile hallucinations. It can be fatal if not treated promptly and properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's encephalopathy: It is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics. Symptoms include ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis: It is a chronic neurologic sequelae of alcoholism resulting from prolonged thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and lack of insight.

 

Option D. Alcohol-induced psychosis: It is a rare complication where patients present with hallucinations after heavy, prolonged alcohol consumption but without other features of withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: A pregnant lady comes to the OPD for a regular check-up. She has decreased iron levels and the doctor prescribed her iron medication. Which of the following decreases the iron absorption from the gut? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tea


Iron absorption in the gut is influenced by various dietary factors. Vitamin C, found in foods such as amla (Indian gooseberry), lemon juice, and sprouts, enhances iron absorption by converting ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which is more readily absorbed.

 

On the other hand, substances like tannins and polyphenols, which are abundant in tea, inhibit iron absorption.

 

When tea is consumed with meals, the tannins bind to non-heme iron (plant-based iron), forming insoluble complexes that are not easily absorbed by the gut. This reduces the overall bioavailability of dietary iron. Thus, drinking tea during or shortly after meals can significantly decrease iron absorption, which is particularly important to avoid in individuals with iron deficiency, such as pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amla: Rich in vitamin C, amla enhances iron absorption by converting Fe3+ to Fe2+.

 

Option B. Lemon juice: A citrus fruit high in vitamin C, which aids in iron absorption.

 

Option D. Sprouts: Also high in vitamin C, promoting better iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea contains tannins that decrease iron absorption from the gut by binding to non-heme iron and forming insoluble complexes.

questions.text: Which parameters would you utilize to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programmer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Annual Blood Examination Rate

 

Annual blood examination rate (ABER): (Index of operational efficiency)

 

 

 

ABER is a critical parameter used to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program. It reflects the proportion of the population that is being tested for malaria and helps determine the operational efficiency of the surveillance system. High ABER indicates effective surveillance and control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual parasitic incidence (API): Sophisticated measure of malaria incidence in a community

 

 

Option C. Slide positivity rate (SPR):

 

 

Option D. Slide falciparum rate: specifically measures the proportion of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum, the most severe form of malaria. It indicates the burden of P. falciparum in the population.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Adenylyl cyclase
Guanylyl cyclase
Phospholipase C

questions.text: Beta 2 receptor action leading to hyperglycemia/ hypoglycemia is mediated by which of the following enzymes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adenylyl cyclase

 

Explanation

 

Beta 2 receptor action leading to hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia is mediated by adenylyl cyclase.

 

Catecholamines act through beta 2 receptors and they use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system to stimulate the target tissues.

 

Cyclic AMP is synthesized from ATP by the action of the enzyme adenylyl cyclase.

 

  • Binding of the hormone to its receptor activates a G protein which, in turn, activates adenylyl cyclase
  • The resulting rise in cAMP turns on the appropriate response in the cell by either (or both):
    • Changing the molecular activities in the cytosol, often using Protein Kinase A (PKA) — a cAMP-dependent protein kinase that phosphorylates target proteins
    • Turning on a new pattern of gene transcription

 

Cyclic AMP produces one or more of the following responses:

 

  1. Contraction and relaxation of muscle fibers
  2. Alteration in the permeability of cell membrane
  3. Synthesis of substances inside the cell
  4. Secretion or release of substances by target cell
  5. Other physiological activities of the target cell

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guanylyl cyclase: Incorrect. While guanylyl cyclase also produces a cyclic nucleotide (cGMP) that acts as a second messenger, it is not involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Incorrect. Phospholipase C is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, not Gs-coupled receptors like the beta-2 receptors. It catalyzes the breakdown of phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate, which are involved in calcium signaling.

 

Option D. Phospholipase A2: Incorrect. This enzyme liberates arachidonic acid from phospholipids, leading to the production of eicosanoids (like prostaglandins and leukotrienes). It is not directly involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other hormones that use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system are:

 

  • ACTH
  • Angiotensin II
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone
  • Calcitonin
  • FSH
  • Glucagon
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone
  • HCG
  • Luteinizing hormone
  • Parathyroid hormone
  • Secretin
  • Somatostatin
  • TSH
  • Vasopressin

choices.text: Positive feedback
Negative feedback
Adaptive control regulation

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

 

Explanation

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels

 

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves →nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla→ release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) → inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feedforward: Incorrect. Feedforward control involves responses that anticipate changes, typically without a direct sensor feedback component, which is not applicable to the baroreceptor reflex.

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies an initial stimulus, leading to an even greater response. In contrast, the baroreceptor reflex mitigates changes in blood pressure to restore equilibrium.

 

Option D. Adaptive control regulation: Incorrect. While adaptive control involves adjustment based on feedback, it is more complex and typically involves adjustments over time to control parameters. The baroreceptor reflex specifically uses a simpler, direct negative feedback mechanism to quickly counteract changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The baroreceptor reflex is a prime example of a negative feedback mechanism in human physiology, crucial for maintaining stable blood pressure by counteracting deviations from an individual's normal blood pressure set point

questions.text: A bank employee, felt depressed with no interest in activities, came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea, or excessive saliva production, is not a common side effect of SSRIs like escitalopram. It is more commonly associated with the atypical antipsychotic drug clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia, or difficulty achieving orgasm, is a well-known side effect of SSRIs due to their impact on serotonin levels, which can interfere with sexual function.

 

Option C. Nausea: Nausea is one of the most common side effects of SSRIs. It typically occurs at the beginning of treatment and may subside with continued use.

 

Option D. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams are another common side effect of SSRIs. They occur due to the influence of increased serotonin levels on sleep patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Escitalopram is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).
  • Other SSRIs include Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Fluvoxamine etc.
  • Side-effects of SSRI include:
  • Most common: Nausea, Vomiting
  • Next most common: Anxiety etc.
  • Other side effects- Delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, diarrhea, vivid dreams etc.
  • Main drug which causes sialorrhea is CLOZAPINE (an atypical anti-psychotic drug)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/488

choices.text: Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

questions.text: A patent underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The histopathology specimen reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscularis propria. What is the next best step? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

 

  • In the scenario of a patient with a gallbladder carcinoma discovered incidentally following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, where the carcinoma has invaded the muscularis propria, the next step in management should focus on ensuring complete removal of any residual malignant tissue and preventing local recurrence.
  • Radical or wide excision of the gallbladder fossa is the recommended course of action. This involves excising the gallbladder bed to the level of the liver parenchyma and possibly lymph node dissection to ensure any potential spread or residual disease is addressed. This approach is supported by the need to achieve negative margins, as gallbladder cancer can be aggressive and has a tendency to infiltrate the liver and surrounding structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy and B. Chemotherapy might be considered as adjunct therapies depending on the stage of the cancer, pathological findings from the re-excision, and the patient's overall health status. However, they are not the primary step immediately following the discovery of invasive gallbladder cancer in a post-cholecystectomy specimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical/wide excision of the GB fossa is indeed the appropriate next step to prevent local recurrence and potentially improve survival outcomes. This decision is based on the depth of tumor invasion and the general aggressiveness of gallbladder cancers.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushes to OPD today with complaints of upwards rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

The patient is experiencing oculogyric crisis, which is an acute dystonic reaction caused by antipsychotic medications. This is an extrapyramidal side effect that involves sustained, involuntary upward deviation of the eyes.

 

This is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties. It's commonly used as the first-line treatment for acute dystonic reactions, including oculogyric crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lorazepam: Useful for generalized dystonia or akathisia but not the first line for acute oculogyric crisis.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Another antipsychotic, it wouldn't directly treat the acute dystonic reaction.

 

Option D. Stop antipsychotic: While it might be necessary to review and adjust the antipsychotic regimen if a patient is having side effects, simply stopping the antipsychotic won't provide immediate relief from an acute dystonic reaction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect, is characterized by spasm of muscles in any part of the body, e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis. It is seen in about 10% of patients on antipsychotics. Risk factors include young males, those who are antipsychotic naive and high potency antipsychotics. It usually occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic medication. They can be distressing but are reversible. Anticholinergic agents like promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111

choices.text: NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available
NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

questions.text: The image of the mascot ‘Sapna’ shown below and identify what does she represent in the national health program: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

 

'Sapna' is the mascot of National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP) in India. She represents the success story of leprosy treatment, as she herself was a leprosy patient who got completely cured after taking multi-drug therapy (MDT). Her role is to spread awareness about:

 

  • Curability of leprosy through MDT
  • Reducing stigma and discrimination associated with leprosy in society
  • Encouraging early detection and treatment seeking behavior
  • Demonstrating that leprosy patients can lead a normal life after treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available: Incorrect because there is no widely accepted vaccine for leprosy currently available for public use

 

Option B. NLEP, Leprosy has been eliminated: While India achieved elimination status (<1 case/10,000 population) in December 2005, the program continues as new cases still occur

 

Option D. NLEP, leprosy can't affect children: Incorrect as leprosy can affect people of any age group including children

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sapna is the mascot of NLEP who represents successful treatment of leprosy and aims to reduce stigma while spreading awareness about curability of the disease through multi-drug therapy.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

 

Explanation

 

Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.

 

This hormone is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.

 

  • 24 Hours After Delivery: Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours after ovulation: Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.

 

Option C. NREM Sleep: Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion.
