Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.

 

Option D. After running for 1 hour: Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:

 

During sleep, the hypothalamus releases dopamine, which inhibits the secretion of jectiveprolactin. As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.

 

Prolactinoma: The most common cause of hyperprolactinemia is a noncancerous tumour of the pituitary gland called a prolactinoma.

 

Medications: Certain medications can increase prolactin levels. These include antipsychotic (such as risperidone and haloperidol), antidepressants, anti-nausea drugs (such as metoclopramide), and some high blood pressure medications.

 

Hypothyroidism: Underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can disrupt the normal balance of hormones in the body, including prolactin regulation.

 

Chronic Kidney Disease: Kidney dysfunction or chronic kidney disease can lead to hyperprolactinemia. Impaired kidney function affects the clearance of prolactin from the blood, leading to elevated levels.

 

Stress and Emotional Factors: Extreme stress, emotional trauma, or intense physical activity can temporarily raise prolactin levels.

 

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding: During pregnancy, prolactin levels increase to prepare the breasts for milk production. After childbirth, prolactin levels remain elevated to stimulate and maintain breastfeeding.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

Let's match the descriptions to the terms:

 

A. Depression : "Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.

 

B. Suicide : "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.

 

C. Burnout : "State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.

 

D. Overthinking : "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.

 

So, the correct matching would be:

 

A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bohler Braun splint 

 

  • It is a common splint used in wards for immobilization and reduction of most lower limb fractures and treatment of other lower limb pathologies.
  • Structure:
    • It consists of an iron frame with a set of 4 pulleys for application of mobile traction. 
    • It is modified from Braun splint which consists of only 1 pulley for distal tibia or calcaneal skeletal traction. 
    • Bohler’s Modification was addition of 2 more pulleys for proximal tibia and distal femur traction.
  • Uses of 4 pulleys:
    • Lowermost pulley is used for tibia and fibular injuries
    • Second from bottom is used for supracondylar fracture femur
    • 3rd (directed away from patient) is used for fracture shaft femur middle third
    • 4th (topmost and directed towards the patient) is used to prevent foot drop
  • Uses:
    • With traction:
      • For lower limb injuries with displacement/fragment overlap. 
      • The skeletal traction is given via a K wire, Steinman pin, Bohler's pin, etc.
      • In leg fracture, pin goes through calcaneal tuberosity
      • In femur fracture, pin goes through tibial tuberosity in adults, and just above the condyles in children
    • Without traction:
      • Compound fracture with no overlap – for dressing and wound care, and possible immobilization
      • Soft tissue injury to leg
      • In case of cellulitis, gangrene, amputation, etc.
  • Advantages:
    • Mobile traction – especially useful in cases where transportation is necessary as the traction unit is self-contained
    • Places the limb in comfortable position
    • Wound care is possible
    • Multipurpose application
    • Angle of traction can be changed by changing the pulleys without changing the arrangement 
    • Simultaneous traction through Calcaneal/distal tibia and proximal tibia/distal femur can be given
  • Disadvantages & complications:
    • Non-ambulatory
    • Stiffness/contracture
    • Urination and defecation becomes difficult
    • Common peroneal nerve compression
    • Other complications of recumbancy like bed sore, hypostatic pneumonia etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thomas splint: The Thomas' splint aims to immobilise the limb and consists of a padded metal ring (either continuous or with an opening, and a strap and buckle on the lateral side) covered with soft leather, attached to an angled bar that extends down the length and both sides of the leg. The bar is usually angled over the hip at the greater trochanter and the two side bars join in a “W” shape at the foot. The ring is available in different sizes to enable it to fit appropriately around the patients' groin (over the ischial tuberosity) and across the gluteal fold. This enables the splint to fit the patient as closely as possible. 

 

 

Option B. Volkmann splint: The Volkmann splint, also known as the Volkmann's turnbuckle splint, is a specialized orthopedic device used to treat Volkmann's contracture. Volkmann's Contracture is a condition that occurs when there is a lack of blood flow to the muscles of the forearm, leading to permanent shortening and tightening of the muscles, resulting in a claw-like deformity of the hand. The Volkmann splint is designed to gradually stretch and lengthen the shortened muscles. It works on a 3-point fixation mechanism and has a turnbuckle that controls and adjusts the tension.

 

 

Option D. Cramer wire: The Cramer splint is a simple but effective medical device that is used to fix fractures. Structurally, it is a reusable medical part in the form of a narrow ladder made of steel or aluminium wire, the flexible elements of which are soldered together. It can be given any shape, anatomically following the contours of the injured limb. It is used for fractures of the lower and upper extremities – shoulder, forearm, hip, ankle, ankles and fingers. In addition, it is used for reliable fixation of the patient’s upper spinal column and head. Immobilization of injured limb using a Cramer splint reduces the level of pain and prevent from additional damage during transportation of the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the Bohler-Braun splint which is used in the immobilization of the lower limb fractures. 
  • The splint consists of a system of pulleys to provide traction and allow for fracture healing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Graves' disease with eye signs and enlarged thyroid is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. What medication can be administered in the preoperative period to minimize intraoperative bleeding in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium iodide

 

Potassium iodide, which can be given 10 days before the surgery to reduce intraoperative bleeding during total thyroidectomy. This is because iodide alone produces transient remission and may reduce vascularity, thereby marginally improving safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to prepare the patient for surgery by inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and causing beta-adrenergic blockade. However, it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding during thyroidectomy. It is beneficial in thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Propylthiouracil: Propylthiouracil is an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. It is used to render the patient euthyroid before surgery, but it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Option D. Betamethasone: Betamethasone is a glucocorticoid that reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. However, it is not used preoperatively in thyroidectomy to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in an overactive thyroid gland, known as hyperthyroidism. In this condition, the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing it to produce more thyroid hormone than the body needs. As a result, the thyroid gland becomes hyperactive, leading to various symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism. Graves' disease is the most prevalent cause of hyperthyroidism.

choices.text: Increase dose of haloperidol
Change haloperidol to clozapine
Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol

questions.text: A patient of Schizophrenia was started on antipsychotic drug haloperidol. Few hours later, he presented with torticollis and muscular dystonia. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Give benztropine

 

When a patient on haloperidol develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) like torticollis and muscular dystonia, the next best step is typically to administer an anticholinergic medication like benzhexol or benztropine to alleviate these side effects. Increasing the dose of haloperidol would likely worsen the EPS, while changing to clozapine is an option for patients with severe EPS or a history of non-response to other treatments. Fluphenazine is unlikely to be significantly different from haloperidol in causing EPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose of haloperidol: Increasing the dose of haloperidol is not the appropriate response when a patient develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as torticollis and muscular dystonia. It can exacerbate these side effects.

 

Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is less likely to cause EPS compared to typical antipsychotics like haloperidol. Switching to clozapine can be a reasonable option to manage EPS.

 

Option C. Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol: Fluphenazine is another typical antipsychotic and is not expected to be significantly different from haloperidol in terms of causing EPS. Switching to fluphenazine may not effectively address the EPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to manage extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) caused by antipsychotic medications. It can be an appropriate choice to alleviate the torticollis and muscular dystonia.
